**Government policies, macro-economic conditions and performance of the power generation, transmission and distribution sector**

Our business is intrinsically linked to the performance of the power generation, transmission and distribution sector in India and international markets. Projects in this sector are primarily undertaken or awarded by governmental authorities and entities funded by the central and state Governments. We currently derive and, in the future expect to derive a significant portion of our revenue from power generation, transmission and distribution projects in India which are dependent on budgetary allocations made by central and state Governments, public bodies as well as increasing access through private sector funding. We believe that sustained increase in budgetary allocation for and the participation of public bodies, coupled with comprehensive policies that encourage greater private sector participation and funding will result in the growth of this sector. Macroeconomic factors such as rising power demand for residential, industrial and commercial purposes, increased usage of electricity in rural economy, higher focus on renewable energy and related governmental policies thereof, will have a significant impact on our prospects and results of operations. Furthermore, broader economic indicators such as GDP growth, foreign investment regulations, oil and commodity prices, interest rates, tariffs, access to capital, export market regulations and overall financial stability may significantly influence the economic landscape of the country, and by extension, the viability and scale of investment in power transmission and distribution. A change in policy resulting from a change in government (including change in central government and/or state governments of regions where our projects are located) may also impact our business. These shifts could affect project approvals, funding mechanisms, and strategic priorities in the power generation, transmission and distribution sector.

Our restated consolidated summary statements of profit and loss (including other comprehensive income) and restated consolidated summary cash flow statements for the years ended March 31, 2023, March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025 included in our Restated Consolidated Financial Information, reflect the split between our continuing and discontinued operations. Our restated consolidated summary statements of assets and liabilities as at March 31, 2023 does not include any split between continuing and discontinued operations and our restated consolidated summary statement of assets and liabilities as at March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025 reflect only our continuing operations. Accordingly, our restated consolidated summary statements of assets and liabilities as at March 31, 2023 is not comparable with our restated consolidated summary statements of assets and liabilities as at March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025. Consequently, any financial information as at March 31, 2023 is not comparable with the corresponding information as at March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025. See, also “*Risk Factors – Our financial information as at March 31, 2023 is not comparable with our financial information as at March 31, 2024 and March 31, 2025.*” on page 65.
